column4: only one version how gparted can exist at a time, so your question is infact bsaeless :)
If you used synaptic it would have asked you to remove the older gparted if you wanted to install a new one conflicting packages
I downloaded a .tar.gz and then I ran the install. so now I have an executable inside the folder, which is gparted.
I go to that folder but I cannot launch it.
can you do this sudo apt-get remove gparted
Umm so my download was useless ... *Sighs*
and then sudo apt-get install gparted
on what basis does it upgrade it?
if you do sudo apt-get upgrade, all your installed software including gparted will be updated so theres no need to install/download a new version
I just run apt-get update, yes ?
if you are using graphical apps try gksudo <app_name> as in gksudo gedit
thats the same as sudo but for graphical apps it behaves more nicely :)
